2.text: Truly I have known that it is so, And what—is man righteous with God?

3.text: If he delight to strive with Him—He doth not answer him one of a thousand.

4.text: Wise in heart and strong in power—Who hath hardened toward Him and is at peace?

5.text: Who is removing mountains, And they have not known, Who hath overturned them in His anger.

6.text: Who is shaking earth from its place, And its pillars move themselves.

7.text: Who is speaking to the sun, and it riseth not, And the stars He sealeth up.

8.text: Stretching out the heavens by Himself, And treading on the heights of the sea,

9.text: Making Osh, Kesil, and Kimah, And the inner chambers of the south.

10.text: Doing great things till there is no searching, And wonderful, till there is no numbering.

11.text: Lo, He goeth over by me, and I see not, And He passeth on, and I attend not to it.

12.text: Lo, He snatches away, who bringeth it back? Who saith unto Him, ‘What dost Thou?’

13.text: God doth not turn back His anger, Under Him bowed have proud helpers.

14.text: How much less do I—I answer Him? Choose out my words with Him?

15.text: Whom, though I were righteous, I answer not, For my judgment I make supplication.

16.text: Though I had called and He answereth me, I do not believe that He giveth ear to my voice.

17.text: Because with a tempest He bruiseth me, And hath multiplied my wounds for nought.

18.text: He permitteth me not to refresh my spirit, But filleth me with bitter things.

19.text: If of power, lo, the Strong One; And if of judgment—who doth convene me?

20.text: If I be righteous, Mine mouth doth declare me wicked, Perfect I am!—it declareth me perverse.

21.text: Perfect I am!—I know not my soul, I despise my life.

22.text: It is the same thing, therefore I said, ‘The perfect and the wicked He is consuming.’

23.text: If a scourge doth put to death suddenly, At the trial of the innocent He laugheth.

24.text: Earth hath been given Into the hand of the wicked one. The face of its judges he covereth, If not—where, who is he?

25.text: My days have been swifter than a runner, They have fled, they have not seen good,

26.text: They have passed on with ships of reed, As an eagle darteth on food.

27.text: Though I say, ‘I forget my talking, I forsake my corner, and I brighten up!’

28.text: I have been afraid of all my griefs, I have known that Thou dost not acquit me.

29.text: I—I am become wicked; why is this? In vain I labour.

30.text: If I have washed myself with snow-water, And purified with soap my hands,

31.text: Then in corruption Thou dost dip me, And my garments have abominated me.

32.text: But if a man like myself—I answer him, We come together into judgment.

33.text: If there were between us an umpire, He doth place his hand on us both.

34.text: He doth turn aside from off me his rod, And His terror doth not make me afraid,

35.text: I speak, and do not fear Him, But I am not right with myself.
